title: Jeremy Corbyn defends record on anti-Semitism after MP quits
text:
Leader of the British Labour Party Jeremy Corbyn | Sean Gallup/Getty Images Jeremy Corbyn defends record on anti-Semitism after MP quits Louise Ellman leaves Labour, saying party ‘permits anti-Jewish racism to flourish.’

Jeremy Corbyn defended his record on tackling anti-Semitism on Thursday, after MP Louise Ellman quit the party and called the Labour leader "not fit" to be prime minister.

"I have taken the most resolute action possible of any party leader to deal with issues of anti-Semitism or racism of any form in our party," Corbyn said as he arrived at a meeting of European socialist leaders in Brussels.

Ellman, the MP for Liverpool Riverside, wrote a scathing resignation letter, describing Labour as a "party that permits anti-Jewish racism to flourish" and accusing Corbyn of "attracting the support of too many anti-Semites."

Corbyn thanked Ellman for her work in the Labour Party and defended the party's record on anti-Semitism. "I’ve set up an inquiry into it, we’ve set up an education process and we have suspended and indeed expelled members," he said.

"There is no place whatsoever in our society or in any other for anti-Semitism, Islamophobia or any other form of racism," he said, adding that he would hold this stance until his "dying day."
description: Louise Ellman leaves Labour, saying party ‘permits anti-Jewish racism to flourish.’
